comments.commentBody: I agree. Please stop all the silly conspiracies!

"We got some criticism when we said we were going to get rid of ‘topic of your choice,’ ” says Scott Anderson, director of policy for the Common Application, but it’s “so open-ended that unless students are very skilled writers, they’re hindered by the lack of focus.”

Umm - the student who can effectively answer that is whom I would want in my classroom!
Is your work peer reviewed? By whom!

Can't you find a self-publishing path? I know of young people who have done that with fiction. Reaching the public is a lot different now than it was when I was young. I hope you can find a way. And I hope you have a real treatment that works. I can't help but think about the heartbreak of the people who believed in "guided communication."

After years of research, I am fully confident that I know the cause of Autism. My conclusions also explain the elevating affliction rates and range of manifestations. I have authored a book that establishes a foundation, identifies influential components, highlights observations, and draws conclusions comprising the basis for the discovery. It also recommends a simple action plan for parents to prevent Autism instead of dealing with fear or mitigation.

I have attempted to move this to publication but have been surprised and disappointed by the lack of response. I imagine either a) publishers simply can't believe that one person can define the cause, or b) the healthcare industry is financially reliant on Autism and is apprehensive about a revelation of the cause. In the meantime, children suffer and families deal with the ramifications.

A publisher or member of the medical community could easily say "Really? I'd like to know more." We could then a dialog to move this into the public forum and put an end to the suffering. Autism typically manifests within three years of birth, so that's the maximum time needed to establish the viability of the theory.

If you know someone who can help, I invite you to respond. If you just want more information, please wait for the book. If you think this isn't possible, recall Thomas Edison or others whose tenacious application of common sense and effort resulted in surprisingly simple but vastly influential discoveries. That still works.

One of my dear friend has a severely autistic child.  I see them occasionally due to distance and family schedule.  This child was a beautiful baby, when he reached the age of 8 or 9 months I thought he wasn't a very "responsive baby", never looking at you in the eye, never laughing like a normal baby.  I didn't think much of it at the time.  When the kid was 2, not speaking (not even mama or dada), I sensed something was really wrong. My friends do an excellent job raising this child and having a life, but this is not a fun experience at all.  The kid can't stay with a sitter, only his parents or the therapists is used to.   I want to invite them to an important and formal family event, yet I don't know what they are going to do with the kid.  The last time, they stayed 10 minutes because the kid was screaming and running all over the place.  I am at loss and dread the day when I will have to tell them no to bring the kid.
Judy, you are not an autistic adult. Please do not tell Chris and me - two people who ARE - that we shouldn't exist.

Because if you don't make eye contact you are unable to proofread, alphabetize, ring up orders, find lost items, make schedules, program a computer...?

This is something where a reasonable accommodation can be made. Refusing to hire people because they do not make eye contact is a violation of the ADA. It really is not an integral part of any job.

Autism is a physical condition linked to abnormal biology and chemistry in the brain. The exact causes of these abnormalities remain unknown to this day.  In no way autism and homosexuality may be compared.  A child who cannot communicate, who can't be toilet trained, who throws tantrums daily and whose parents cannot go out with the child is a really handicapped kid. It 's a sad fact.

A variable perhaps not controlled for is how much contact these babies had with their caregivers, be it touching, auditory or visual. And other variables are incredibly controlled. The bables were watching media-- not real people. Any other stimuli which connects them to a source that they are tracking has been taken out.

As an older child who was a subject of early psychophysiological experiments at Fels-Kettering lab, I can tell you that being hooked up to all the monitors while watching a screen significantly altered my perception of my mother's performance in a contest vs another adult woman's. The gadgets and the environment probably had the biggest impact on me.

This seems like ground breaking research but I hope there will be more cross-referencing done regarding all the ways that sensory input is received including in relationship with caregiver.
Can't say as I blame them, Uly; seeing as how you've made yourself their spokesperson.

I hope this isn't a typical Times reader.  Misreading the reference to Gravity, which was a wonderful film--not quite 2001, but well beyond the gravitas of recent space epics; and changing the topic, not even with a meaningful digression, but with the dull thud of dementia tripping on a rug. So sad.

THis is hardly news, but I guess the desire to measure and quantify  ourselves  is irresistible. Of the course the brain/mind limits us- healthy people mind you- chronic disease/medications are another animal.
Why would anyone want to go to a respectable school, especially in that least respectable state of Texas?

I know my mom uses sex toys. I know I use sex toys. I know my sisters use sex toys. I assume my father does with his current wife. Honestly, I'm glad that we're all experiencing the pleasure our bodies are designed for. Should the task fall to me to clean out their belongings after their demise, I'll be glad they continued to experience pleasure as long as they did.

Sex is sex. Sometimes it's procreative and sometimes it's just for pleasure. Why the shame or horror of discovering hard evidence that our family members have sex?

No pun intended.

In a previous life, when I was a young journalist covering the statehouse beat, I was having lunch one day with a wonderful lady who was an experienced colleague on the paper I worked for. She confided in me -- strictly off the record -- that her brother, a conservative Republican politician who had to her great embarrassment become prominent in the "family values" movement, had secretly commissioned her to retrieve and destroy what I took to be his rather extensive hidden stash of porn, if and when it ever became necessary.
Thought about that story when I read this piece. I recall reading this gentleman's obit a few years back and wondering whether his instructions were carried out.
Reminds me of the time our cat dropped my wife-to-be's diaphragm at my mother-in-law-to-be's feet.

On a family visit to my sister's house my two-year-old momentarily disappeared down a hallway while we all stood around the kitchen greeting, exchanging hugs. As I started after her, she excitedly ran back into the room waving an ENORMOUS life-like dildo, squealing "What dis? What dis?"

At least my sister will never have to worry about appointing an Eradicator--she has already been outed by her niece!
Oh fooey!  Puritanical and prudish I am not and never will be.
We ALWAYS open things we are told not to open.
How old are you, Michelle, thirty?

Well said. Speaking as someone who has had to clean out my mother's house - Wadler has found a way to make the subject of sex toys a vehicle for a boring kind of narcissism .

After storing a room full of my mother's antiques and memorabilia I eventually got rid of almost all of it. The objects were only meaningful to me, because I had seen and experienced them in the context of my mother's life and my own youth.

To my kids - my mother's sewing machine was just a thing. It had no special meaning in and of itself.

Joyce, I hate to break it to - but our old junk is just - um - junk.

Oh my... another article of your obsession with mortality... my my my... hon- your days are numbered, okay? Move on and squeeze the most juice you have out of the days left. It's the richest by far.

As far as my toy collection... (cough cough) .. If my children find these intimate devices, they would do as I did (I hope) when I found my Mum's... they'd have a laugh and smile..

And then shed a tear because they missed me.

Wow. Talk about humourless....

I sincerely hope your day improves!

I have served as a self-appointed eradicator. I do it secretly and superficially; just a quick sweep. I never found anything obviously embarrassing, but there were a couple of modest stashes that may have disturbed other family members.

So, Ms Wadler, your building has a distinct recycle container for vibrators?
Disagree. It was funny, something that seems beyond you.

I meant to say "less is more". As we age I think it's most important to find the sweet spot with exercise.

And we are all different.
As is needing to post lame comments.
Needing to both get drunk and exercise in a large group is impossibly lame.

wah - great - but don't be like the drunk guy on the bicycle in Ireland - pedaling home after a night on the turps - crashing into the hedge - before maybe being arrested for 'drunk in control of a vehicle' ...
The article was about ATHLETES who are PHYSICALLY FIT and NOT those just STARTING out. It pays to READ the article before making a GENERALIZAION.
